Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Laser Cutting Technology for Borehole Sampling
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will take initial development steps toward a laser-cut ice-sampling capability in glaciers and ice sheets. The collection of ice samples from the Polar Ice Sheets involves large amounts of time, effort, and expense. However, the most important science data are often retrieved from small sections of an ice core and, while replicate coring can supplement this section of ice core, there is often a need to retrieve additional ice samples based on subsequent scientific findings or borehole logging at a research site. In addition, there are currently no easy methods of extracting ice samples from a borehole drilled by non-coring mechanical drills that are faster, lighter, and less expensive to operate. There are numerous science applications that could potentially benefit from laser-cut ice samples, including sampling ice overlying buried impact craters and bolides, filling critical gaps in chemical records retrieved from damaged ice cores, and obtaining ice samples from sites where coring drills apply stresses that may fracture the ice. <br/><br/>This award will explore a laser cutting technology to rapidly extract high-quality ice samples from a borehole wall. The project will investigate and validate the existing technology of laser ice sampling and will use a fiberoptic cable to deliver light pulses to a borehole instrument rather than attempting to assemble a complete laser system in an instrument deployed in a borehole. This offers a new way of retrieving ice samples from a polar ice sheet without the need to drill a borehole to collect ice-core samples (i.e., the hole could be mechanically drilled). This technology could also be used in existing boreholes or those that are made by augering through ice (i.e., not coring) or made with hot water. If successful, this technique would create the ability to rapidly retrieve ice samples with a small logistical footprint and enable science that might not be supportable otherwise. The proposed technology could eventually provide better access to ice-core samples to study past atmospheric composition for understanding past climate and inform on future potential for ice-sheet change.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advancing technologies continue to enhance the recovery and sampling of ice cores for paleoclimate research. The process of collecting deep ice cores is intricate and involves extensive planning and complex fieldwork support in remote locations. While existing mechanical ice core systems are effective, they can only extract a relatively small cylinder of ice. For ice of special importance, such as layers deposited during rapid climate transitions, conventional drilling does not yield a sufficient volume for analysis. Pilot studies on laser “cutting” of ice have shown promise. Laser cutting also offers an improved method for extracting ice from brittle regions without causing stress. In a collaboration between the University of Minnesota (UMN) and the University of Maine, laser cutting experiments were conducted at the UMN laboratory using a new Yb-doped fiber laser. These new lasers are reliable and flexible in deployment, with tunable parameters that greatly minimize mechanical or thermal stress during ice cutting. The series of experiments were aimed to optimize laser cutting settings  for sampling ice at conditions resembling ice sheet settings. 

The main focus of UMaine’s team in the project was to test how laser cutting at cold temperatures that resemble ice sheet settings impacts the integrity of the samples. Encouragingly, results showed no measurable impact on the integrity of ice core samples when ice fracturing or thermal exposure was minimized. However, it is important to note that sample sizes  were limited to relatively large pieces (> 5 mm thick) of laboratory-made ice of known chemical  composition. Project results support the concept of future use of a portable sonde equipped with a laser cutting system for large volume ice sampling from boreholes. Because  it is very resource intensive to build a contamination-free testing apparatus, we suggest that real-world settings using natural ice samples might be more suitable for testing future laser sampling systems.

The demonstrated ability of new laser technology is encouraging and can be transferable to other research fields that use ice to place seismic or neutrino  detectors (e.g., ice seismology, IceCube observatory) or build portable sampling systems for space exploration.

The project’s interdisciplinary nature provides a unique platform that fosters close interaction of engineers, paleoclimate scientists and chemists to address important issues related to several  NSF 10 Big Questions: reconstructing Earth's past climate and atmospheric conditions, using complex paleoclimate data in advancing data science and analytics; improving analytical techniques and sensors. Several students and a postdoc from  UMN  were part of the team addressing these important topics. 

Project results were presented at meetings and workshops for the ice core, paleoclimate and glaciological  communities, as well as demonstrations for local K-12 students and the general public during visits to the UMaine Climate Change Institute facilities.
